{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3385658,"name":"avi","username":"mar56vel","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/b77776/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-14T13:08:30.274Z","cooked":"

my team been having trouble with our CNC lathe, specifically with the limit switch.
when we home the machine, it works fine on all axis except on the X axis. it just keeps going back even after it passed the limit switch, and it just ends up hitting the back. was wondering if anyone had a similar problem? and if changing the limit switch on that axis fix it?

BenchTurn 7000 Turning Center,

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2024-05-14T14:05:32.402Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":165,"readers_count":164,"score":33.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":466220,"topic_slug":"limit-switch-cnc-lathe","display_username":"avi","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":1082,"username":"sanddrag","name":"sanddrag","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/c68b51/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":60010,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/limit-switch-cnc-lathe/466220/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3385739,"name":"Steven Smith","username":"Steven_Smith","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/8e8cbc/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-05-14T15:44:12.808Z","cooked":"

On a simple limit switch on these budget level lathes there are two failure modes, fail to trip, and fail to reset. Like Brandon mentioned, you can connect a multimeter to the switch and look for continuity. The limit switch could be wired either for normally open (no beeping with switch not pressed), or normally closed (beeps when switch isn‚Äôt pressed). My preference would be to wire normally closed, that way if you severed the wire (opening it), it would trip, but different manufacturers implement differently.

So if you say ‚Äúhome‚Äù, and it travels in that direction and doesn‚Äôt hit anything‚Ä¶ it could be the limit switch is just broken. It could be the cam/block/mechanically thingy the limit switch hits at full travel is missing/loosened/slid/etc.

For reference, these are the type I have on my machine. The roller element hits a wedge shaped block to engage it.

The other failure mode is fail to release. So it goes, trips the switch to find home, and starts backing away from the limit switch to set home position‚Ä¶ but the limit switch never pops back out, so it moves several inches away from the switch and then faults out. This has happened a few times to me with flood coolant getting into the cheap limit switch and gumming it up. You can spray anything in there compatible with your coolant (or I just use fresh coolant), and work it in/out a few times, to un stick it.
